title: 103_hr1511
content:
The Act is titled the "Agricultural Commodity Export Expansion Act of 1993". The Congress recognizes the importance of agricultural commodity exports to the US economy, with one-third of harvested acreage worth over $40 billion in exports. The newly-formed Republics of the former Soviet Union are in need of agricultural imports to support their transition to democratic government and free market economies. The former Soviet Union has been a major importer of United States grain, and the new Republics are seen as a crucial market for US agricultural products in the future. The recent halt in US agricultural exports to the former Soviet Union Republics has negatively impacted US agricultural producers, potentially adding $1.3 billion to the US deficit if not reversed. The Republics' abundant natural resources and revenue-generating capacity from resource development assure their ability to repay US loans for agricultural exports. The United States has extended authority for the export of agricultural commodities and products, including direct loans, credit guarantees, and programs for barter with importing countries. This is in addition to existing programs like the Export Enhancement Program and the Dairy Export Incentive Program. The United States has programs like the Export Enhancement Program and the Dairy Export Incentive Program for exporting agricultural commodities. Additionally, there is the Sunflower Oil Assistance Program allowing sales to third-country buyers for commodities destined to the former Soviet Union. Buyers relying on compensatory trade forms can be eligible for USDA trade program bonuses. Recipient countries can make payments based on future sales of their natural resources for US agricultural commodities. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS FOR DIRECT LOANS.

Section 201(f) of the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 is amended to consider credit needs, repayment ability, and maintaining US competitive position in world markets for export sales financing. 

SEC. 4. RESTRICTIONS FOR CREDIT GUARANTEES. The amendment to Section 202(f) of the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 now considers credit needs, repayment ability, and maintaining US competitive position in world markets for credit guarantees on agricultural commodity sales.
